description: From Middle English plentie, plentee, plente, from Anglo-Norman plenté, from Old French plenté, from Latin plenitatem, accusative of plenitas (“fullness”), from plenus (“complete, full”), from Proto-Indo-European *pl̥h₁nós (“full”), from which English full also comes, via Proto-Germanic. Related to the Latin derivatives complete, deplete, replete.

adjectives.description: plenty (comparative more plenty, superlative most plenty)

examples: if reasons were as plenty as blackberries
This office is plenty big enough for our needs.

entries.meaning: (Canada, US, colloquial) Used as an intensifier, very.
examples: She was plenty mad at him.
We are lucky to live in a land of peace and plenty.
